slides.name: toss
slides.prompt: Tap a sequence of 12 coin flips. Make it look as random as possible; another person should think it really happened.
slides.instructions: This experiment investigates how humans produce and perceive randomness. It consists of three very short tasks related to chance. A suggested pace is one tap per second.
slides.warning: ⚠️ You can’t undo or go back.

slides.text: The study got a bit of attention on dozens of outlets. The headline: A person’s ability to be random peaks at 25 years old and declines after 60.
We initially set out to use the findings to make an age guessing game, but after analyzing the data we lost confidence it would yield good results.

We don’t think the study’s findings are reproducible because of the researchers’ decision to include “bad” responses. To us, a bad response means the participant either misunderstood the instructions, or intentionally sabotaged the experiment. That decision was the difference between “ah this is interesting” and “welp, nothing here” (or “null results” in statistics lingo).
Here are the instructions from the original study:
Here is an example of a <mark class=good>good</mark> and <mark class=bad>bad</mark> dice roll sequence based on their classifying algorithm.

Do you think the bad response looks “real” and satisfies the instructions? We don’t. The researchers behind the study did (and confirmed with us via email). And this disagreement has a big statistical impact.
Here is the key chart from the study that shows the developmental curve of complexity for the coin toss experiment.

steps.text: Think of the complexity score as a proxy for randomness; higher up means more random, lower down means less random. Here are a few <mark class=good>examples</mark> (H for heads, T for tails).
Here is your score. Your answer got a higher random score than of people in the study.
When we add a <mark class=good>trend line,</mark> we can see the age drop-off finding take shape.
At the bottom are the <mark class=bad>bad responses</mark>. We even took a conservative approach to defining bad; just the ones that were entirely heads or tails.
When we exclude the bad responses, the trend disappears.

slides.text: Although that example was just for the coin toss, the trend line has the same shape when you look at the aggregate results.

The study was peer-reviewed, not reproduced. This is typical since reproduction takes significantly more time and effort. It is quite likely that the reviewers didn’t run their own data analysis either, which means it was easier to miss a small but important decision like the one we found.
The experiment at the start of this story was our attempt to do our own abridged reproduction. Here are the live results of that process from <mark></mark> (not bad) reader responses.

Since this chart is being created on the fly, we can’t tell you what it looks like. But our hypothesis is that it is more or less a straight line. Are we right? If so, we haven’t found any correlation with age and randomness. If not, then perhaps there is something worth exploring further!

The moral of the story: just because you read a New York Times headline about a study doesn’t mean others have been able to reproduce the same results, so stay curiously skeptical. Maybe you knew that, in which case we hope you enjoyed this breakdown. If you did, consider supporting The Pudding and its contributors on Patreon.

methods.value: The calculation of algorithmic complexity is done using the CTM method. In practice, we use a custom implementation of the acss R package to obtain this complexity for given user inputs and compute an overall score.

For the task level data, we use the original dataset of the study and use a cutoff non-uniform responses to remove “bad” ones. We then overlay this data with a trend line calculated using the LOESS (locally estimated scatterplot smoothing) method.
